snippet: Hezbollah’s role has further antagonized sectarian divisions in Syria and beyond, creating new risks for both the Syrian government and the militia even in their moment of victory.
abstract: Hezbollah’s role in helping Syrian government combat rebel forces is further antagonizing sectarian divisions in Syria and beyond; situation creates new risks for both government of Syria's Pres Bashar al-Assad and Hezbollah allies from Lebanon; Hezbollah has been revered in Syria for its opposition to Israel, but now Syrian insurgency views group as having turn its guns on fellow Muslims and become an occupying force.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by an employee of The New York Times from Daba’a, Syria, Hwaida Saad and Hania Mourtada  from Beirut, Nick Cumming-Bruce from Geneva, Alan Cowell from London, Steven Erlanger from Paris, Thom Shanker from Washington, and Rick Gladstone from New York.

lead_paragraph: Hezbollah’s role has further antagonized sectarian divisions in Syria and beyond, creating new risks for both the Syrian government and the militia even in their moment of victory.

headline.seo: In Syrian Victory, Hezbollah Risks Broader Fight
headline.main: In Syrian Victory, Hezbollah Risks Broader Fight
headline.print_headline: In Syrian Victory, Hezbollah Risks Broader Fight
